comments.text:
+goatcheese guru the only reason that I think this would be considered 
weird is because you don't see caterpillars acting as teams in nature. 
There are certain characteristics that some animals have such as if they 
are pack or solidary predators. And caterpillars from that I have seen have 
always been solidary animals as in no cohabitation with another 
caterpillar. So seeing caterpillars work together in such a unique way is 
fascinating

comments.text:
imo, the weird part is that it's thought of as weird. We, as humans, do 
this so frequently, just as [somewhat] individuals. And then you have 
Humans operating as one inside a business, to accomplish common goals. 

I'd think our neurons go about thinking in a very similar process. just a 
lot faster. Also i think organisms such as the Manowar Jellyfish are 
actually just a collective sum of different microorganisms/polyps working 
together as one unit.

comments.text:
the more layers the faster I think. its only 2 layers there but in theory 
if the bottom/base caterpillar's speed does not change because of the 
weight of the upper layers than the speed should be 100% with every 
layer.... I think... I donno I am stuck on how fascinating this matter is. 
they do not only seem as a big animal over many small ones discouraging 
predators to attack but also move faster and to add to that they also make 
group decisions... I wonder if anyone ever did a proper study on this or if 
its a new thing they just developed lately... like those birds that in just 
a couple of years developed new skills to protect their nest from the 
parasitic cuckoo birds that were laying eggs there. That's also a 
fascinating story about how under threat of extinction evolution sometimes 
does not wait for thousands of years and just happens in one generation. 2 
different species under threat by this phenomenon developed in just couple 
of years 2 different skills to protect from that. One specie developed a 
song that it sings to the eggs and when they hatch only the same specie 
chicks can reproduce it so the mother only feeds the right ones, and one 
specie changed the spot patterns on the eggs to recognize them and to push 
aside the egg that does not belong to it. This just happen as researchers 
were looking for ways to fight off the cuckoo invasion that sent on the 
endangered list several bird species.

top_comment.text:
In the first Lego example the top Legos travel at twice the speed. But the 
bottom Legos travel at normal speed.
So if you had and even amount of Legos on the top and bottom, they would 
average 1.5 faster than the single Lego.

But in your example, there are fewer Legos on top, which means fewer Legos 
going twice as fast. So I would say it's just a little slower than 1.5x 
faster.﻿

comments.author: GengarWarrior

comments.text:
this hive behavior can really be broken down to what behaviors of this 
insect species allow them to survive the longest. The instincts and 
impulses that have allowed them to survive are really what you are 
witnessing. A group huddling together makes them less susceptible to birds 
swooping down and snacking on them one by one. Same with the interval 
movement. Unless some animal is focusing on them for longer than a minute 
they will probably miss the fact that this is actually food crossing the 
jungle floor...

starts moving, like a chain reaction.

or the back.
They stop moving when one caterpillar decides to stop.

comments.author: 1jtwister

comments.text:
+Jason Aricheta I'm not talking about insects that damage you. I'm talking 
about animals that are harmlessly living near you. But rather than killing 
cockroaches, it's good to find out where they come from.
Protect your sugar by putting the sugar bowl in another bowl with water. 
Ants can't pass water. They also can't pass layer of petroleum jelly.
If your home is clean, ants will not find it as interesting as homes of 
your neighbours.

Talking about luxury, I have two spiders on my ceiling. They're doing 
pretty good job killing sleeping mosquitoes when I sleep. (mosquitoes hang 
on the ceiling, and spiders kill them while they sleep).

Anyway, the point is, when animals are causing you harm, I understand that 
you try to get rid of them. But most ants and most caterpillars are not 
doing anything bad to you or anyone else.
comments.author: Jakub Mareda

top_comment.text:
Crowd Walking

Collective locomotion, demonstrated by this species of Amazon caterpillars, is inspiring robotics: http://goo.gl/zpNB5

Caterpillars can also move in long processions. Read more about collective behavior here: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3605510/

#ScienceSunday   #SciSunRR
top_comment.author: ScienceSunday

comments.text:
+Rajini Rao I coincidentally came across these two photos of the European 
processionary caterpillar which I took a few months back.  They also form a 
moving clump like the Amazon caterpillars shown above but very much so tend 
to form a single line. 
https://plus.google.com/u/0/109593846255852899186/posts/D7W8yjKEvkj

comments.author: Andrew Planet

comments.text:
The peripheral nervous system is huge! The part of the peripheral system 
that controls heart beat or breathing is called autonomous, but what's cool 
is that it can be regulated by the sympathetic/parasympathetic nerves: 
that's how our heart can beat faster when we are scared, etc.
comments.author: Rajini Rao

comments.text:
+Rajini Rao Just read the fabulous post you offered.  So it seems that the 
spinal column has a brain of its own then.  I saw a TED talk once that 
explained that in terms of neurons we have the equivalent in size to a 
cat's brain in our stomachs.  I find that the terms afferent and efferent 
help a lot to imagine to one's self in what directions all this happens. 
 The little I know of this I remember by thinking afferently affected, 
efferently effected.
comments.author: Andrew Planet

comments.text:

http://thumbiology.blogspot.com/2011/03/voluntary-and-involuntary-actions.html

What I really liked about Iain Couzin's talk was his analogy of collective 
behavior to humans driving on autopilot.
comments.author: Rajini Rao

comments.text:

comments.text:
He asked for the term of the Collective locomotion of the catepillars? 
 They seen to be moving as in a group procession, as in a group of people, 
rather than as in solitary but similar file as done by the processionary 
caterpillar http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pine_Processionary.  He also asked 
how the group could stop and seemingly think its next move gregariously. 
 Flocks of starling moves together by sets of simple laws effected by the 
individual bird and htis has already been studied greatly by scientists. 
 The only difference to the starlings seems to be an actual parameter of 
touch which only these catapillars have.  When one stops a tug that is felt 
seems to occur between individuals bridged by others.  At least that's what 
I hypothesise as a non entomologist.  A procession of caterpillars. As in 
the European processionary caterpillar but not in a single file.

comments.text:
+Víktor Bautista i Roca , perhaps the comment under discussion was 
analogous to the statement, "I could care less". In that case, what is 
actually meant is that they *couldn't* care less ;)
Back to science: the linked article and video make the case for many 
advantages of collective behavior, other than the obvious one of fooling 
predators. The video indicates that collective movement is faster than the 
individual. The paper explains how collective behavior in caterpillars may 
be important for thermoregulation.
comments.author: Rajini Rao

comments.text: +Mark Bruce +Koen De Paus
comments.author: Drew Sowersby

top_comment.text:
The group moved 36 pegs in the same amount of time the solo moved 19 pegs. 
So the ratio between them was 1.89. It's not exactly double, but that makes 
sense considering that the blue in the group has double speed most of the 
time (when crawling on the backs of others) and normal speed part of the 
time (when being crawled on). Therefore almost twice as fast with with two 
layers and I'd hypothesize that more layers would be faster but you might 
run into weight issues.﻿
top_comment.author: Zack Poirier

comments.text:
+Fabrício Lara I was talkin about a 3 rows situation.. think about it... 
first lets start with a cat travelling in the second row. once it reaches 
the head of the row,it will need to get back at the tail of the group 
before it can get access to the 3rd row. thus, it will use the slowest 
route, ie, the bottom row to get to the tail. then it'll use the 3rd row to 
get to the head again. once at the head, it'll again have to use the bottom 
row to get to the tail before it can go to the second row to complete the 
cycle... thus 2x bottom row and 1x mid and 1x top row.
comments.author: Pi5hvi

comments.text:
+Evancarrick12
Or you could simply say that when a caterpillar is on top, it moves at 200% 
speed and when it is on bottom it moves at 100% speed. Therefore, if it 
spends equal time on top and bottom, it averages a speed of 150%. If the 
caterpillar spends more time on the bottom, that specific caterpillar will 
appear to move closer to 100% speed. If it spends more time on top, it will 
appear to move closer to 200% speed. The blue caterpillar in this case 
spent most of its time traveling on top, therefore it will have an average 
speed closer to 200%. This is, of course, disregarding factors like weight 
slowing them down and how often they pause their movement.
comments.author: xSirDingo

comments.text:
You also need to factor in the stopping and starting, sure its 1.89 times 
faster if they were going non stop but I'm curious what the ratio of going 
to not going is
comments.author: John Johnson

comments.text:
+Pi5hvi , why do you think that each cycle consists of 2 passes at the 
bottom row? If that was true, the bottom row would have twice the number of 
caterpillars as the other rows, which I believe is false. I believe 
(ignoring the border effects) each row must have the same number of 
caterpillars, and so the mean speed of the group equals to the arithmetic 
mean between each row's speed.
With that hypothesis:
1 row = 100%
2 rows = (1+2)/2 = 150%
3 rows = (1+2+3)/3 = 200%
4 rows = (1+2+3+4)/4 = 250%
...

But, of course, the speed decreases with more weight above. So the group 
speed is less than what I predicted here.
comments.author: Fabrício Lara

comments.text:
Wrong. You are not counting the whole cycle. In the example Destin sets the 
blue caterpillar only moves 3 spaces at x1 speed and the rest at x2 speed. 
That's why yo get that average x1.89 speed.
If you count the whole cycle, with X spaces moving at x1 speed and X spaces 
moving at x2 speed, the average speed would be (1*X+2*X)/2X = 1.5, like +
Evancarrick12 says.
comments.author: maqueterobcn

comments.text:
+Evancarrick12 you r totally right, just an expansion, for a 3 layer 
caterpillar mound, the problem is slightly more complex, the dynamics of 
their motion would be such that to complete a cycle, each caterpillar would 
move once in the middle row, then once in the bottom row then in the top 
row,and once again in the bottom row befor going back tto the middle row, 
so essentially, each cycle consists of 2x bottom row speed, 1x mid row 
speed, 1x top row speed, the solution would be (0.5x1) + (0.25x2) +(0.25x3) 
= 175% of single caterpillar speed... i think the progression here is 
pretty clear...
1 row = 100% (ie same as single caterpillar speed)
2 rows = 100 + 50 = 150%
3 rows = 100 + 50 + 25 = 175%
results here on out are not varified but gotten through extrapolation.. so 
may be wrong...
4 rows = 100 + 50 + 25 + 12.5 = 187.5%
5 rows = 193.75%
6 rows =  196.875%
7 rows = im positive a bird eats em before they  get to 7 rows!!
comments.author: Pi5hvi

comments.text:
Try not to just count what he did, instead think about the situation.if 
there is one caterpillar on top for each one on the bottom, then the 
problem is extremely simple. you have half (1/2 or 0.5) the group moving at 
double speed (200% speed, or 2), and half the group moving at normal speed 
(100% or 1). The problem therefore becomes: (0.5x1)+(0.5x2)=group speed. 
That works out to 150% of single caterpillar speed. From that equation it's 
pretty simple to play with the numbers and either add layers, or change the 
number of caterpillars on each layer.
comments.author: Evancarrick12

top_comment.text:
Great vid. The increase in speed of the group is a factor of the number of 
caterpillars and layers. The bottom layer always moves at the same pace as 
an individual but every time a caterpillar gets to the front on the 
accelerated levels it effectively gets the group ahead by 1 caterpillar, 
allowing the rearmost to climb and hitch a ride. ﻿
top_comment.author: mzaalam

comments.text:
Sadek cheaib, you're right extra weight would cause the current bottom 
layer caterpillars to expend more energy, so I think the term more 
efficient is incorrect. However, the caterpillar mass if not more efficient 
is much faster, and speed is the key concept here.
comments.author: Super Bug

comments.text:
There is no efficiency because of the weight of the others above. The 
energy the one below has to use is x3 the normal one.
comments.author: sadek cheaib

comments.text:

comments.text:
That's an excellent question and a hard one to answer. General consensus 
now is (for some cancers) that there is a "leader" cell that has the 
migratory and invasive capacity, and that the other cells "follow' because 
the homotypically adhere to their neighboring  cells through adhesion 
receptors on their membranes. It is believed that the leader cells have 
directional movement either through chemotaxis or 'guidance' by the 
microenvironment.

comments.author: Soda Sama

top_comment.text:
The increased speed of the lego movement is a "trick" that wouldn't apply 
to caterpillars. Don't watch the blue lego, as suggested. Instead watch the 
front of the collection of legos. Every time a lego block on the second 
layer extends it's entire "body length" over the lego below, it drops down, 
increasing the distance by four clicks at once (instead of one). This would 
only work with caterpillars if the top layer of caterpillars were extending 
their entire body lengths over those below, then dropping down. As you'll 
see from observing the video, this doesn't happen.﻿
top_comment.author: Beau Quilter

comments.text: +Beau Quilter Ok.
comments.author: Joshua Wonser

comments.text:
+Joshua Wonser I think it's pretty clear that the lego model is 
demonstrating a type of forward motion that is not happening with the 
caterpillars. All of the "speed" of the lego mass is gained when entire 
blocks drop off the end, increasing the lego mass by a an entire block 
length in one move. Caterpillars do not do this.
comments.author: Beau Quilter

comments.text:
+mrmyc0rn No. The caterpillar that gained speed on top may reach point B 
before a caterpillar at the end of the mass; but the mass as a whole is 
still traveling at the same rate. If you are running across the deck of a 
large ship, you may personally reach the port before the people at the rear 
of the ship; but the ship itself reaches the port no sooner.
comments.author: Beau Quilter

comments.text:
+Beau Quilter Perhaps the caterpillar steps are faster for those coming off 
the front, since they are still partially on top of a moving caterpillar. 
The Lego model demonstrates the ideal version of what would happen, but we 
do not know enough about the inefficiencies.
This discussion is pointless without empirical evidence of a single 
caterpillar versus a caterpillar mass.
comments.author: Joshua Wonser

comments.text:
+Beau Quilter Please don't think me rude or bothersome, I'm just trying to 
wrap my head around this one... Suppose this cluster of caterpillars is on 
a long trek from point A to point B. Any given caterpillar is moving, at 
its slowest, regular caterpillar speed while at the bottom of the pile, 
right? But while at the upper levels, he moves twice or three times faster 
(or more, depending on how many levels there are), wouldn't that 
caterpillar - and all the other caterpillars - HAVE to reach point B a lot 
quicker than just being in a single layer?
comments.author: mrmyc0rn

comments.text:
+Joshua Wonser The progression may continue to move forward, but the 
caterpillars stepping off the top do not increase the speed of the whole 
mass, which continues to move forward one caterpillar step at at time.
comments.author: Beau Quilter

comments.text:
+mrmyc0rn I agree that it's probably about camouflage or defense in some 
way. Yes, the caterpillars on top do move faster, in a way, but the mass as 
a whole does not move faster. When the "faster moving" caterpillars on top 
step off, they do so with only a few legs at a time, just like the 
caterpillars beneath. This is not the case with the legos. When the a lego 
drops off the end of block of legos, it adds its full body length to the 
distance travelled, and this is where all the speed gain comes from. The 
caterpillars do not drop off the end at full body lengths as the legos are 
manipulated to do.
comments.author: Beau Quilter

comments.text:
+Beau Quilter Do you mean that the bottom layer are not moving? I think 
they are. They don't stop moving just because they reach the front and drop 
down to the bottom layer, do they? I don't understand why it would not be 
just like when you continue to walk while on a "moving sidewalk" at the 
airport. The bottom layer makes up the "moving sidewalk". Or, the first of 
several moving sidewalks stacked upon each other. Why isn't the Lego 
simulation accurate?
(I don't believe it's about efficiency for the catarpillars, anyway, but 
camofluage)
comments.author: mrmyc0rn

comments.text:
+Beau Quilter We need more observational data to measure the true 
difference in speed from a single caterpillar, but I think you are 
incorrect in stating all extra speed is lost.
Look at 1:59 to 2:01 in the clip at 0.25 speed. As the front top 
caterpillars are climbing to the ground the ones behind them are 
simultaneously climbing on top of them, so it keeps the progression moving 
forward. There are likely inefficiencies that the lego model doesn't 
capture, but it does a good job in conveying the main point of what is 
happening.
comments.author: Joshua Wonser

comments.text:
+A crow Mind The collective behavior likely helps camouflage as you point 
out, but that doesn't negate this interesting property of faster travel. 
Both seem to be benefits of the grouping, and the video didn't claim faster 
travel was the only reason they cluster.
comments.author: Joshua Wonser

comments.text:
+뿡뿡! ^__^ No, you misread me. I said that "it's a demonstrate of what is 
NOT happening". You are probably correct that it is a misunderstanding. 
That does not make my statement incorrect (or silly).
comments.author: Beau Quilter

comments.text:
+Beau Quilter That is a silly comment. If the demonstration is 
misunderstanding and misrepresenting what is actually happening, then it is 
not a demonstration of what it happening. It is a misunderstanding.
comments.author: 뿡뿡! ^__^

comments.text:
+Naval Kishore Barthwal It's a demonstration of what is not happening to

comments.author: Beau Quilter

comments.text:

might increase in speed as he moves across the top of the group, but all 
that extra speed is lost when it slows down to tentatively step off the 
front of the group.
comments.author: Beau Quilter

want to move , it is going to be stationary. But if that lazy caterpillar

ground.
comments.author: Naval Kishore Barthwal

top_comment.text:
OK so it's faster when you're on top, and just nothing when you're on 
bottom. However, when you're on bottom you have to spend extra energy still 
because you're carrying your own weight + the weight of whoever's walking 
on top of you. So from an energy efficiency point of view, even if you're 
moving faster as a whole, it uses more energy to achieve that boost in 
speed. I think that's the tradeoff. If you were alone you could also spend 
extra energy to move faster: running.﻿

comments.author: Wet Pants

comments.text: are you replying to me, or are you upgrading my comment?
comments.author: Quentin “SpecialBomb” Jankosky

comments.text:
Actually one lego would be less painful. The bottom of feet are soft and 
squishy. So if he steps on one lego, (roughly guessing) 5% of the surface 
of the bottom of his foot is on a lego, while the other is distributed on 
the ground. You would also have to take in where the lego is under his 
foot, as more weight is spread out at the heal than the toes. So my best 
judgement would be, if one lego were stepped on under the heal, it would 
cause moderate pain due to the thick skin, compared to if the lego was 
under the middle of hit foot(the bridge) where the skin is thinner and more 
sensitive. While the toes would be rather unharmed. However, if he were to 
step on legos(plural) more of the surface of his foot would be on legos, 
meaning more weight would be placed on all of them. Yes it means the weight 
distributes, however in both ways it distributes, one means more weight on 
ground, many means more weight on legos.
comments.author: Wet Pants

captions.text: [music]
Hey it's me Destin welcome back to Smarter Every Day.
I'm in Caleb's room. Caleb is a science fair winner, so he is
legit, and you dropped the cat in the cat drop video right?

- Yes.
- And we had a deal right? I paid you with something. What did I pay you with?

- These Lego motors.
- That's pretty cool.
But I called you and I said I want you to build something for me for a video. What is it?
- This Lego inchworm. This battery pack allows
the motor to turn, which powers the axle,
the worm wheel, the cam which drives the whole thing, and this
ratchet, it allows the worm to move in one spot

so it doesn't do this.
- That's awesome. Oh when you take the ratchet off it doesn't
work so you have to put the ratchet back on? So it pushes against itself.
That's awesome. So I have been fascinated as long as I can
remember with locomotion. That's why Caleb got these motors. So today
on Smarter Every Day we're gonna look at caterpillar locomotion. But we have to go back to the Amazon rainforest
to see it. It's a group of caterpillars doing something really strange.
Let's get Smarter Every Day.
So check this out. Gordon found a big caterpillar that's basically
a macro organism of a bunch of little caterpillars.
And they're all moving as one.
That's weird.
- They all stop and think at the same time too. See that?

(Destin) Gerson, do you know a word for this?
- No.
- See they all stop at the same time.
- Oh that's weird.
If you look, like for a
school of fish or birds it's usually the bird or the fish in front that dictates where the whole
group goes. But if you look at the caterpillars when they're stopping they're doing this little
stop and think technique, you'll notice that it propogates from the back to the front sometimes.
That's really strange. I wonder what kind of clock or rhythm is dictating this.
I don't know. Look at it. Really weird.
Alright note to self.
Go back and look at the video of the caterpillars and see if the ones on top
are moving twice as fast as the ones on bottom, or depending on how many layers up they are
if they're moving like three times as fast. So it wasn't until I got here and started playing with Legos that I
realised it's not only the second and third level of caterpillars that's moving faster,
it's the entire group as a whole. OK to demonstrate this we're gonna have a Lego drag race. You can
see I've got a single caterpillar on this side and I have a whole group of caterpillars on this side.
At each frame I'm gonna move the single caterpillar one click and I'm gonna move the ones on
bottom one click as well as the ones rolling across the top one click. Keep your eyes
on the blue caterpillars. Ready, set, wiggle.

caterpillar that was by himself is a lot slower than the caterpillar that was in the group.
Now we had two levels. So does that mean that this moved twice as fast?
No it doesn't. Do the math for me by looking at these grids and let me know in the comments how much
faster. But think about this. What if we had three levels or even more?
How much efficiency do the real caterpillars add every time they add a level?
